metadata.name: Kyma #163
metadata.description:
Kyma (/kee-ma/, κύμα) is a Greek word meaning wave. It is my exploration of an acoustic phenomenon known as ‘Chladni Patterns’. 

Ernst Florens Friedrich Chladni was a German physicist and musician. He was a pioneer of modern acoustics and made numerous contributions to the field. Chladni's work had a significant influence on the development of modern music theory and the technology of musical instruments. In 1787, Chladni was trying to understand how sound waves propagate and interact with objects. By vibrating a metal plate and sprinkling sand on it, he observed that the sand arranged itself into distinct patterns. These patterns are created due to the interaction between the sound waves and the plate: the sound waves cause the plate to vibrate, which in turn causes the sand to move. The sand will move away from areas of high vibration and towards areas of low vibration. This creates a unique pattern of ridges, circles, and many other shapes.

Kyma continues this study by adding color, light, and composition to the equation. Each iteration is a unique combination of two Chladni plates with different characteristics, accompanied by a palette, background lighting, and variational drawing algorithm. Plates interact with each other, forming patterns from the small detailed net-like grid to megalithic sculptures of unknown creatures and windows to another worlds.

Please use fullscreen or download artwork in high resolution for a better viewing experience.

Rendering can be computationally heavy, please be patient and give it some time to draw.
Chrome is highly recommended for live mode and high res saving.

Made with love, math, and p5js. 

Controls in fullscreen:
[1] - save PNG 2400 x 1600
[2] - save PNG 4800 x 3200
[3] - save PNG 9600 x 6400
[4] - save PNG 14400 x 9600

metadata.name: Experiment No.4 - Theory #61
metadata.description:
Results of an old experiment continue to be inputs to the new experiments!

”Experiment No.4” is a generative artwork coded by True Neutral, January 2023.

Total 26 palettes with 15 vanilla filter!

Special thanks to @Clete, @Neppenthe, @Hiceku

Press "S" to save a .jpg of your token in Open Live.

metadata.name: Nullteilung #92
metadata.description:
Nullteilung is another exercise in suprematism and composition. Born from a series of exercises in subdevision and tesselation, it seeks to connect with the user through the creation of a sense of order and balance in the composition.

The term "Nullteilung" a German word that can be translated to "zero division" which is suggesative of the order and disorder paramount in the piece, working toward a goal of emotional and programmatic purity.

metadata.name: Element #208
metadata.description:
Element is a generative series of pixelated mosaics that explores two contrasting styles of generative art. One style embraces imperfection and noise to simulate paint or other real-life textures, while the other produces digital outputs with precise forms.

The mosaics were inspired by the works of Hiroshi Kawano, one of the pioneers of generative art. They are generated by randomly placing rectangles inside a grid then applying a Markov-chain process multiple times. A hand-drawn and organic style is then incorporated using various techniques such drawing many rectangles with subtle variations in colour for a paint texture or adding different kinds of noise.

Please view in full-screen for the best experience.

Press [s] when the output is fully rendered to download it as a png file. The resolution can be set by adding for example "&s=2048" to the url for a 2048 x 2048 output.

Element was released as part of the Cure3 exhibition, generating vital funds for Cure Parkinson's medical research.

metadata.name: Morixels Mega Colab #1 #330
Mineral Composition #7
metadata.description:
Since its conception, this project has been modified over the past seven months by adding new elements and techniques to improve its overall aesthetic and impact, as well as my own skills as a generative artist.
Mineral Composition is an artwork inspired by the natural beauty and complexity of minerals: crystalline and ordered arranges of ionic elements. As an admirer of nature, I have been particularly drawn to the way that just a simple atomic rearrangement in the presence of certain metals can result in a merge of vibrant colors, brightness, and contrast.
My deep appreciation for this subject grew even stronger during my master's degree in Materials Science, which led me to search for a way to incorporate this knowledge into generative art. The idea to use k-means clustering to play with mineral colors came to me during a casual chat with a very clever friend (Estienne). They suggested trying this machine learning algorithm, which involves grouping similar colors into clusters and selecting representative colors from each cluster.
I was immediately intrigued by the idea and decided to give it a try. I gathered a selection of 20 mineral images and used them as samples for the clustering system. The results were nothing short of stunning - the algorithm was able to identify and extract a wide range of colors from the minerals and would have been difficult to replicate using traditional methods.
I knew that this approach to color selection would be a game-changer for my artwork, and I was eager to put it into action. Using the colors extracted through k-means clustering, I was able to create a truly one-of-a-kind color palette for each minted generative token one that perfectly captured the essence of minerals in all their vibrant and varied hues. And the best thing is even with repeated picked minerals, the palette won't never be the same.
Additionally, the FF-based drawing can vary in three models and, when combined with various texture elements such as irregular grids, geometrical patterns, and stained canvases, provides the viewer with a pleasing experience by allowing them to examine every single detail across the entire canvas.
"The main intention was to create a piece that would have a fine art feel and be suitable for printing at high resolutions to be displayed as part of an environment's decoration. To achieve this, I took great care in crafting every detail of this work, ensuring that it could be reproduced and enjoyed in all its detail and intricacy by collectors.
Overall, Mineral Composition is an art piece that combines multiple basic and medium techniques of creative coding and machine learning. It is a project that captures the essence of minerals in a completely innovative way and will be a welcome addition to any art collection.

_______________________________
Variety of editions is guaranteed by several features:
* Backgrounds with paper colors or with a picked color from the mineral palette.
* 20 real minerals as color samples to create infinite palettes by k-means clustering.
* Controlled variety of scale;
* Controlled variety of particle number;
* Animation time;
* Symmetrical mode (mirror mode) possibility (15%);
* Three drawing models for FF filaments (opening and closing screws or spring screws.

_______________________________
Interactive instructions:
After finishing the animation, press:
* [L] to check your mineral and palette info;
* [K] to save your .png file in screen size (smaller);
* [n = 2 to 5] to save your .png file in A[n] ISO216 printable sizes;

Depending on the RAM and CPU usage, it takes from a few seconds to a minute to render the image.
Advice: the system needs enough free RAM for rendering A2 sized images. It was tested on Chrome, Brave, Firefox, Opera, Edge and Safari, but please make sure it works on your device before. 
_______________________________
Prints can be ordered. Shipping costs to discuss. DM me on twitter for more information!
_______________________________
Creator: Kukuti
Made with p5.js
January 2023
License: CC NY-SA 4.0

metadata.name: Watercolor Studies #39
metadata.description:
Watercolor Studies
In honor of #fxhashturnsone

50% of primary proceeds are donated to The Processing Foundation.
https://processingfoundation.org

80% of royalties go back to the original minter.

Controls:
Press [s] in live mode to save as PNG.
DM for a hi-res copy ;)

Thanks to everyone who participated in this event and even greater thanks to the fx(hash) team and all their amazing hard work!

Acknowledgments to ’The Book of Shaders’ for providing most of my knowledge throughout my Shaders journey.

Made with p5js and Shaders
November 2022

metadata.name: Dots #179
metadata.description:
Titled as a play with colors and shapes created from dots, Dots started as a collection on Objkt, extended to 8bidou and had new developments in Exchange Art. It was a dream to be able to make a collection of Dots on Fxhash, now it finally happened. Initially we only had 1 color palette, however, to create more variety, this project has 7 color palettes. To create the palettes we chose 5 famous artists to honor, including Peter Halley, Max Bill, Piet Mondrian, Sophie Taeuber and Lygia Clark, in addition to the palettes created by us. The project has several grids and some new possibilities in addition to the pieces already created on other platforms. It is with great pride and joy that we present this project made with great affection. Enjoy!

Press [S] to save a image

metadata.name: Temporal #63
metadata.description:
"Temporal" is a generative (pure code) artwork of abstract colored geometric shapes and forms, mixed in a way that trying to simulate natural media

Technically, colored shapes and curves are drawn in a graphic buffer and my custom fragment shader process and transforms the buffer content into that noisy and scratched output. All are 100% code, no images used.

CONTROLS

KEYS:

- 1-4: Set resolution from 1x to 4x of the current dimension (possibly slower performance in higher values)
- S: Save a png file with the current resolution

- P: Change orientation to Portrait with aspect ratio 0.75 (useful eg. for printing)
- L: Change orientation to Landscape with ratio 4/3  (1.333..)
- O: Change orientation to Square (box)
  Due to some 1:1 ratio sensitive calculations, rendering output may differ when switching orientations

----
Made with p5js and custom shaders

ABOUT THE ARTIST
Want to know more ? please read the "SHORT BIO" section here in "Emotions" collection: https://www.fxhash.xyz/generative/22243

© Dec. 2022  @Uniray_net | uniray.net

metadata.name: Gkrint #223
metadata.description:
Gkrint is a celebration of minimalism, colour, and space using the humble grid, a foundation of generative art, and movement. Through this collaboration, Ballzerino and George explore the relationships between these elements.

Inspired by the timeless principles of Bauhaus design, Ballzerino carefully curated custom colour palettes and selected geometric shapes, while George encoded the creative process into an algorithm, bringing the compositions to life, and putting the CPU to work finding new and unexpected compositions within our framework.

Gkrint is Ballzerino's genesis generative art drop.

Controls:
SPACE - pause / resume
click (or tap) - change colour selection (within same palette)
hold 'f' - speed up animation

Tested on Windows / Mac / iOS / Android. Chrome recommended for the best experience.

metadata.name: Artifact #194
metadata.description:
This project is about uncovering artifacts.

Each piece is determined by approximately 15 parameters. This allows for a multitude of possible forms, and each iteration is an artifact to be discovered within the multidimensional space.

This work is focused around discovery. It is about exploring the space of the algorithm, shedding light on its many forms, and sometimes finding artifacts of the real world embedded within them.

Technically, this work is a composition of three primary elements: Voronoi tessellations, orthographic projection, and the depth-sort algorithm.
The latter of these is integral to the rendering mechanism. It works intuitively, drawing distant objects before near objects, evaluating the distance of each object according to its geometric center. It does this precisely, and in doing so, it can produce interesting visual artifacts, drawing some shapes in an unexpected order.



This has been a fascinating study, bringing light to unreal shapes and forms, and uncovering artifacts in an impossible space.

I hope you enjoy it,
Nat Sarkissian





Technical Notes:
- Append “&mag=N” to the end of the URL in live mode to specify a resolution multiplier. It will render the image N times larger than the size of your window. If you have specified anything greater than 1, a download will start automatically once the rendering is done.

metadata.name: The Wintertime #24
metadata.description:
"The Wintertime" is a collection of generative art that captures the essence of the winter season in a glitchy and abstract way. The pieces in this collection are a visual representation of the harshness and beauty of winter, where the cold and barren landscapes are juxtaposed against the sparkling snow and ice. The glitches and digital distortions in the art add a sense of chaos and unpredictability, mirroring the unpredictable nature of winter weather. The collection celebrates the winter season in all its raw and untamed glory. Each piece is unique and evocative, inviting the viewer to get lost in the beauty of the wintertime.

The work was inspired by the drip painting technique of Jackson Pollock and the minimalistic elegance of Japanese prints. Combining these two distinct styles creates a visually striking and thought-provoking collection that pays homage to the masters while pushing the boundaries of contemporary art.

This collection is the continuation of GPTree: https://www.fxhash.xyz/generative/17691

Genuary 2023: Recursive trees

metadata.name: GRAPHEME #66
metadata.description:
Released on the occasion of the Tribute to Herbert W. Franke. 
www.tribute-hwf.com

“One criterion for art involves the process used by the artist for shaping the work. In the special case of mathematically supported fine art, the artmaking process occurs in a mathematically defined operation that allows the generation and transformation of images, methods used for picture processing.” - Herbert W. Franke

I first came across Franke’s ‘Ornamental Alphabets’ in his book 𝘊𝘰𝘮𝘱𝘶𝘵𝘦𝘳 𝘎𝘳𝘢𝘱𝘩𝘪𝘤𝘴 - 𝘊𝘰𝘮𝘱𝘶𝘵𝘦𝘳 𝘈𝘳𝘵, and was intrigued with the idea of using a simple letterform to explore different generative image processing techniques. 

I’ve used letters and writing in my work for a long time, both with letterpress printing and in my asemic poetry programs. With asemic writing, I generate unrecognizable letters to reference text, and here I use recognizable letterforms removed from their typical function as language signifiers. 

My goal with this project was to build as much texture and layering as possible by warping and collaging the letters together in various ways. The font I’m using is a design I made years ago to supplement my wood type collection for printing. I really enjoyed being able to bring that part of my past work into my generative art practice. 

Each image is composed of the letters found in the hash for that piece, divided into either vowels or consonants. The program builds on a technique I’ve used before, where I generate an image to an off-screen canvas and then dive through the pixels to pull out the color and form I want to surface in the final image.

25% of the primary sales will be donated on-chain to the Foundation Herbert W. Franke. These funds will be used by ZKM Karlsruhe to digitize Franke’s 1,800 manuscripts and make them publicly available. Any additional funds raised will be donated to the Rütgers Foundation which supports children and young adults in Africa so that they can get access to and work with technology.

- Press “R” to increase the pixel density and reload the image (this can be render intensive and will create a really large file suitable for printing)
- Press “S” to save a copy

Made with p5js
Artist: Sarah Ridgley
October, 2022
